awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Collaborative Research: Developing, Analyzing, and Evaluating Self-drive Algorithms Using Real Street Legal Electric Vehicles on Campus
awd_abstract_narration:
This project provides hands-on active learning opportunities for undergraduate students to conduct research for urban road self-driving functions using street-legal vehicles. It is uncommon for US undergraduate students to have opportunities to develop self-drive algorithms using real vehicles. In this research, students will analyze and evaluate the results of different algorithms after real-world testing. They will gain knowledge and confidence in self-driving algorithm development, share their knowledge with others through publications, and potentially choose autonomous vehicle research and development as their career path. Student perceptions about the smart mobility field and career options will be positively affected, leading to increased interest in future graduate studies. Evaluation and comparison results of various self-driving algorithms tested are original contributions to the research community. The results will benefit the advance of autonomous vehicle software development, bringing benefits to society including reduced pollution, less traffic accidents and congestion, and lower economic costs.

The specific objectives are to: (1) provide experiences to underrepresented undergraduate students who otherwise might not have research opportunities to learn fundamental theories in autonomous vehicle development; (2) allow students to design algorithms to practice software development using real vehicles on real test courses; (3) strengthen their confidence, self-guided capabilities, and research skills; and, (4) increase the number of students interested in graduate programs and ultimately provide a quality research and development workforce to industry. Activities include (1) intensive daily training workshops with hands-on problem solving tasks with real vehicles; (2) defining research problems; (3) design, implementation, and testing of algorithms; (4) analysis and evaluation of the collected data and results; (5) writing technical reports and presentations; (6) assessments before and after the program; (7) field trips; and (8) post-meetings for publications. This research also advances knowledge by identifying advantages and disadvantages of using real vehicles in teaching and learning self-driving algorithms, plus the most effective strategies to teach self-driving algorithms using real vehicles in order to improve undergraduate education.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Over the course of three summers (2022-2024), this collaborative Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) program, run jointly by Michigan State University (MSU) and Lawrence Technological University (LTU), provided 23 undergraduate students with hands-on research experience in developing and evaluating self-driving algorithms and connected vehicle applications using two full-scale, street-legal electric vehicles. This program aimed to bridge the significant gap between self-driving simulation and real-world autonomous vehicle deployment while fostering student growth in technical proficiency, research skills, and academic and industry career readiness.

Each summer, up to 8 students participated in one or more team-based research projects with a specific research focus on developing robust algorithms for vehicular lane keeping and connected, infrastructure-assisted vehicular control. These students engaged in iterative development, testing their algorithms in simulation before transitioning to full-scale, real-world deployment. The program emphasized interdisciplinary learning by integrating computer vision, robotics, control theory, and real-time systems engineering through an intensive series of workshop modules. Participants also engaged in field trips to academic and industry partners to broaden their horizons, and non-technical instruction sessions focused on reading and writing academic papers and academic career pathways. The program was updated annually based on internal and externally evaluated survey results, student-reported feedback, and instructor observations, with new and updated workshop content, research projects, field trips, and social activities introduced each year.

The program contributed to the field of autonomous vehicle research by training students to develop and evaluate self-driving algorithms beyond the simulation and small-scale environments typical of academic programs and some industry research settings. The students worked with real-world electric vehicle platforms in an outdoor test track, addressing challenges in perception, planning, control, and decision-making for self-driving systems. Student teams developed and evaluated lane-keeping algorithms for real-world navigation under dynamic environmental conditions, implemented vehicle-to-vehicle (V2V) and vehicle-to-infrastructure (V2I) communication protocols, and built a low-cost smart intersection controller enabling hazard avoidance and coordinated automated navigation.

Noteworthy outcomes included the successful deployment and evaluation of novel low-resource lane-following algorithms demonstrating that lightweight, unsupervised learning approaches could reliably operate under constrained computational conditions, outperforming more resource-intensive deep learning models. These algorithms showed high adaptability and effectiveness across varying lighting conditions, road textures, and lane geometries, critical for real-world deployment. Additionally, a novel vehicle-to-everything (V2X) intersection management system was developed, significantly reducing braking and acceleration around traffic signals, leading to improved efficiency, safety, and comfort. Another project introduced a networked, over-the-horizon hazard warning system and an associated collision avoidance algorithm with secondary application to enabling multiple vehicles to safely traverse non-signaled intersections without stopping.

The technical findings of this program resulted in multiple peer-reviewed conference and journal publications, validating both the technical rigor and academic impact of the students' work. Students presented their work at academic conferences sponsored by IEEE and other professional organizations. The students' paper won first place in the 2023 IEOM International Conference on Smart Mobility and Vehicle Electrification "Smart Mobility" competition. The PIs of the collaborative award also published two peer-reviewed papers in ASEE and IEEE education conferences relating to the program design and outcomes, receiving the 3rd best full paper award from the 2025 IEEE ISEC conference. Both PIs also supported K-12 outreach and public engagement through workshops, presentations, digital artifacts, demonstration days, and press releases related to the program, its outcomes, and self-driving more broadly. These efforts are ongoing.

The program significantly enhanced students' technical skills, self-efficacy, and research readiness. Participants gained expertise in advanced software development, sensor integration and signal processing, vehicle and infrastructure communication protocols, and computer vision technologies. External evaluations described in the PI's ASEE and IEEE ISEC publications confirmed substantial improvements in participants' technical proficiency, critical thinking, and problem-solving abilities, particularly emphasizing the value of practical, hands-on learning experiences. These outcomes directly addressed the growing need for skilled professionals in autonomous vehicle technologies.

This program provided intensive training and unique, hands-on research opportunities to multiple students from non-research-intensive institutions, primarily undergraduate institutions (PUIs), and first-generation college students. Over three years, the program successfully increased student confidence in research, with measurable improvements in technical proficiency, research communication, and self-efficacy as evaluated by the program's own external evaluator and CRA CERP. Additionally, several students went on to apply to graduate programs, including those who previously had not indicated such interest.
